newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Another deputy prime minister sacked in Kazakhstan.
newsitem.headline: Another deputy prime minister sacked in Kazakhstan.

text.p: Deputy Prime Minister Nagashbai Shaikenov became the latest victim on Wednesday in a wide-ranging purge of senior government officials in Kazakhstan.
A decree signed by President Nursultan Nazarbayev and published in the former Soviet republic's official press on Wednesday said Shaikenov was moved to "other work" but gave no further details.
Shaikenov, who was in charge of legal reform in the vast, oil-rich Central Asian nation, is one of a string of senior officials to have lost their jobs in the last week.
Another deputy prime minister, Garri Shtoik, who had responsibility for economic reform and high profile foreign investment deals, was sacked on October 28.
The minister of defence and the minister of trade and industry have also been replaced.
Officials have refused to comment on the sackings.
Prime Minister Akezhan Kazhegeldin, widely seen by foreign investors as the main driving force behind market economic reform, has retained his post so far.
Nazarbayev, the country's former Communist Party boss and who has wide-ranging executive powers, restated his commitment to market economic reforms earlier this month.
But some observers say he has lost touch with the tough economic problems facing the government, including growing popular unrest over unpaid wages and pensions.
